{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{other uses|Victory Monument (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox NRHP | name =Victory Sculpture | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | designated_other1_name= Chicago Landmark | designated_other1_date= September 9, 1998 | designated_other1_abbr= CL | designated_other1_link= Chicago Landmark | designated_other1_color= #aaccff | locmapin = United States Chicago | image =Victory Monument Chicago 2.jpg | caption = View facing north | location= 35th Street and King Drive
[[Chicago, IL]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|49|50.6|N|87|37|1.7|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built =1927 | architect= John A. Nyden | customarchitect_title= Sculptor | customarchitect= Leonard Crunelle | architecture= | added = April 30, 1986 | mpsub=Black Metropolis TR | refnum=86001089 {{NRISref|2007a}} }} The '''Victory Monument''', created by sculptor [[Leonard Crunelle]], was built to honor the Eighth Regiment of the Illinois National Guard, an African-American unit that served in France during [[World War I]]. It is located in the [[Black Metropolis-Bronzeville District]] in the [[Douglas, Chicago|Douglas]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]] of [[Chicago, IL|Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. It was designated a [[Chicago Landmark]] on September 9, 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.ci.chi.il.us/Landmarks/V/Victory.html|title=Victory Monument (Chicago)|publisher=City of Chicago Department of Planning and Development, Landmarks Division|year=2003|accessdate=May 7, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410125837/http://www.ci.chi.il.us/Landmarks/V/Victory.html|archive-date=April 10, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The structure was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on April 30, 1986. An annual [[Memorial Day]] ceremony is held at the monument. == Description and history == The [[Smithsonian Institution]]’s [[Archives of American Art]] describes the monument: ::A white granite shaft topped with a bronze [[doughboy]] sculpture. On the monument's shaft are three bronze relief panels depicting life-sized figures. (Victory Panel:) Left full-length profile of a Classically draped African-American female figure representing motherhood. In her hand she holds a branch symbolizing Victory. (Columbia Panel:) Full-length Classically draped female figure with a helmet on her head. In her proper left hand she holds a tablet inscribed with the names of battles in which African-American soldiers fought. (African-American Soldier Panel:) A bare chested African-American soldier of the 370th Infantry, which fought in France, standing with an eagle in left profile in front of him.{{Cite web | title = Victory, World War I Black Soldiers' Memorial, (sculpture). | work = Smithsonian Institution Research Information System | accessdate = February 9, 2014 | url = http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=G29SO53129625.56452&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!8046~!36&ri=5&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Crunelle,+Leonard,+1872-1944,+sculptor.&index=AUTHOR&uindex=&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=5 }} ::In 1927, the State of Illinois erected this monument in the Chicago neighborhood known as "[[Douglas, Chicago#Bronzeville|Bronzeville]]," which was home of the "Fighting Eighth" Regiment of the [[Illinois National Guard]]. The names of 137 members of the [[370th Infantry Regiment (United States)|Eighth Infantry]], Illinois National Guard, who lost their lives during World War I, are inscribed on a bronze panel. The Eighth Regiment of the Illinois National Guard was reorganized as the [[370th Infantry Regiment (United States)|370th U.S. Infantry of the 93rd Division]], and this regiment saw service on WWI major battlefields. It was the last regiment pursuing the retreating German forces in the [[Aisne-Marne]] region of France, just before the November 11, 1918 Armistice. The doughboy on top of the shaft was added in 1936. [[File:Fountain Of The Great Lakes.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Fountain of the Great Lakes]]'' was almost located at 35th and King Drive; it is at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]].]] In 1908 while [[Aaron Montgomery Ward]] was contesting the land use law for [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]] for a second time in the [[Illinois Supreme Court]], the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] considered locating the ''[[Fountain of the Great Lakes]]'' at 35th Street and Grand Boulevard (the latter has been renamed as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive.){{cite book|title=Public Sculptor: Lorado Taft and the Beautification of Chicago|author=Garvey, Timothy J.|year=1988|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=0-252-01501-0|page =17}} Instead, the Victory Monument was installed at this intersection. The [[Bud Billiken Parade]] has for many years traveled along King Drive. In some years, the Parade has started at 31st and King and in other years it has started as far south as 39th and King Drive.{{cite web|url=http://www.uchospitals.edu/programs/community/sponsorships/billiken.html|title=Bud Billiken Parade|accessdate=July 19, 2009|publisher=[[University of Chicago Medical Center]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.budbillikenparade.com/|title=Bud Billiken Parade & Picnic|accessdate=July 19, 2009}} It has often started very near this monument. Recently, the monument has received a grant for restoration as part of World War I centennial activities.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-wwi-centennial-met-20170927-story.html|title=For WWI centennial, six Illinois memorials to get restoration funds|first=Gregory|last=Pratt|publisher=|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=September 28, 2017|date=September 27, 2017}} ==Features== The monument features 4 bronze panels and a sculpture of a soldier atop that was added in 1936. To the north of the monument is a court with 4 plaques in the large [[tile|tilings]]. The plaques honor [[Robert Henry Lawrence, Jr.]], [[Truman Gibson, Sr.]]/[[Truman Gibson, Jr.]], [[Franklin A. Denison]], & [[George R. Giles]]. To the south of the monument is a flagpole that flies the [[United States flag]], [[Municipal Flag of Chicago]], [[POW/MIA flag]]. ==Gallery== Image:20070601 Victory Monument (3).JPG|Close up view facing south Image:20070601 Victory Monument (7).JPG|View facing south Image:20070601 Victory Monument (8).JPG|North walking court plaque Image:20070601 Victory Monument (9).JPG|Memorial plaque Image:20070601 Victory Monument.JPG|Monument and flagpole == See also == *[[370th Infantry Regiment (United States)]] * [[List of public art in Chicago]] ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} == Further reading == *{{Cite book | pages = 214–230 | last = Scott | first = Emmett J | authorlink = Emmett J. Scott | title = Scott's Official History of The American Negro in the World War | chapter = Chapter XV. "The Eighth Illinois" | accessdate = February 9, 2014 | chapterurl = https://archive.org/details/scottsofficialhi00scot }} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.nps.gov/history/NR/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/53black/53black.htm ''Chicago's Black Metropolis: Understanding History Through a Historic Place,'' a National Park Service Teaching with Historic Places (TwHP) lesson plan] {{Registered Historic Places}} {{Chicago Landmark memorials and monuments}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1927]] [[Category:1927 sculptures]] [[Category:Landmarks in Chicago]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Chicago]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Chicago]] [[Category:Military monuments and memorials in the United States]] [[Category:Black people in art]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in Illinois]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Illinois]] [[Category:African-American history in Chicago]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials on the National Register of Historic Places in Illinois]] [[Category:Statues in Chicago]] [[Category:Sculptures of men in Illinois]] [[Category:Sculptures of women in Illinois]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Chicago]] [[Category:Sculptures of African-Americans]] [[Category:African-American military monuments and memorials]] [[Category:Birds in art]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Sick young Bacchus by Caravaggio.jpg | title=Young Sick Bacchus | artist=Caravaggio | year=c. 1593 | medium=oil on canvas | height_metric=67 | width_metric=53 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Rome | museum=Galleria Borghese}}
The '''''Young Sick Bacchus''''' (Italian: ''Bacchino Malato''), also known as the '''''Sick Bacchus''''' or the '''''Self-Portrait as Bacchus''''', is an early self-portrait by the [[Baroque]] artist [[Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio]], dated between 1593 and 1594. It now hangs in the [[Galleria Borghese]] in [[Rome]]. According to Caravaggio's first biographer, [[Giovanni Baglione]], it was a [[Cabinet painting|cabinet piece]] painted by the artist using a mirror.<ref name=Hibbard>{{cite book|last=Hibbard|first=Howard|title=Caravaggio|year=1985|publisher=Westview Press|location=Oxford|isbn=9780064301282|page=19}}</ref>
==History== The painting dates from Caravaggio's first years in Rome following his arrival from his native [[Milan]] in mid-1592. Sources for this period are inconclusive and probably inaccurate, but they agree that at one point the artist fell extremely ill and spent six months in the hospital of Santa Maria della Consolazione.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} According to a 2009 article in the American medical publication ''[[Clinical Infectious Diseases]]'', the painting indicates that Caravaggio's physical ailment likely involved [[malaria]], as the [[jaundice]]d appearance of the skin and the [[jaundice|icterus]] in the eyes are indications of some active [[hepatic]] disease causing high levels of [[bilirubin]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Clinical Infectious Diseases |author= IDSA|publisher=Clinical Infectious Disease |date=Jan 1, 2009 |url=http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/48/1.toc.pdf}}</ref>
The ''Sick Bacchus'' was among the many works making up the collection of [[Giuseppe Cesari]], one of Caravaggio's early employers, which was seized by the art-collector [[Cardinal-Nephew]] [[Scipione Borghese]] in 1607, together with the ''[[Boy Peeling Fruit (Caravaggio)|Boy Peeling Fruit]]'' and ''[[Boy with a Basket of Fruit (Caravaggio)|Boy with a Basket of Fruit]]''.
==Style== {{sectOR|date=May 2012}} Apart from its assumed autobiographical content, this early painting was likely used by Caravaggio to market himself, demonstrating his virtuosity in painting genres such as [[still-life]] and [[portraits]] and hinting at the ability to paint the classical figures of antiquity. The three-quarters angle of the face was among those preferred for late renaissance portraiture, but what is striking is the grimace and tilt of the head, and the very real sense of the suffering; a feature that most Baroque art shares.
The [[still-life]] can be compared with that contained in slightly later works such as the ''Boy With a Basket of Fruit'' and the ''[[Boy Bitten by a Lizard (Caravaggio)|Boy Bitten by a Lizard]]'' where the fruits are in a much better condition, reflecting no doubt Caravaggio's improved condition, both physically and mentally.
The painting shows the influence of his teacher, the Bergamasque [[Simone Peterzano]], in the utilization of the tensed musculature depiction, and of the austere Lombard school style in its attention to realistic details.
==Commentary== [[Cindy Sherman]], as part of her ''History Portrait'' series (1989-1990), produced a parody on ''Sick Bacchus'', an ironic photographic self-portrait named ''Untitled # 224''.<ref>Kimberlee A. Cloutier-Blazzard, [http://breadandcircusnetwork.wordpress.com/2007/07/29/cindy-sherman-her-%E2%80%9Chistory-portrait%E2%80%9D-series-as-post-modern-parody/ Cindy Sherman: Her “History Portrait” Series as Post-Modern Parody], ''Bread and Circus'', 29 July 2007</ref>
During a 2018 [[NPR]] interview, [[Paul Janeway]] of the band [[St. Paul & the Broken Bones]] said that the title of his band's new album, ''[[Young Sick Camellia]]'', is an homage to Caravaggio's ''Young Sick Bacchus'' ([[camellias]] being the [[state flower]] of the band's home state, [[Alabama]]).<ref>{{cite news|title=The Family Blood Of St. Paul & The Broken Bones|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/09/08/645818831/the-family-blood-of-st-paul-the-broken-bones/|accessdate=September 11, 2018|work=NPR.org|date=September 8, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
